paragraphs.text:
%md #Finding large-scale mesoscale convective systems (MCSs) in SciSpark This notebook will demonstrate using SciSpark to: * read in netCDF files * mask areas in an array meeting a criteria * connect these areas via overlap between two time steps to form a graph object. * Search this graph object to find subgraphs meeting a minimum length criteria * Visualization These are all the steps conducted to identify and track mesoscale convective systems (MCSs) as outlined in Whitehall et al. 2014. ![The major steps of the GTG](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/SciSpark/scispark_zeppelin_notebooks/master/images/GTGSteps.png) Figure 1: The major steps of the the Grab 'em, Tag 'em, Graph 'em algorithm For this demonstration, hourly brightness temperature NCEP/CPC MERG dataset over location 5S - 40N, 60E - 90W is used. More information about the NCEP/CPC 4km MERG Dataset used for this demonstration can be found [here] (http://mirador.gsfc.nasa.gov/collections/MERG__001.shtml).
####Useful references * Goyens, C., Lauwaet, D., Schröder, M., Demuzere, M. and Van Lipzig, N.P., 2012. Tracking mesoscale convective systems in the Sahel: relation between cloud parameters and precipitation. International Journal of Climatology, 32(12), pp.1921-1934. * Palamuttam, R., R. Marroquín Mogrovejo, C. Mattmann, B. Wilson, K. Whitehall, R. Verma, L. McGibbney, and P. Ramirez, 2015. SciSpark: Applying In-memory Distributed Computing to Weather Event Detection and Tracking. In 2015 IEEE International Conference on Big Data (Big Data) on, pp. 1959 - 1965. * Whitehall, K., C. Mattmann, G. Jenkins, M. Rwebangira, B. Demoz, D. Waliser, J. Kim, C. Goodale, A. Hart, P. Ramirez, M. Joyce, M. Boustani, P. Zimdars, P. Loikith, and H. Lee, 2014. Exploring a graph theory based algorithm for automated identification and characterization of large mesoscale convective systems in satellite datasets. Earth Science Informatics. DOI: 10.1007/s12145-014-0181-3 Note that in the nomenclature used in this notebook, a *frame* indicates the date and time associated with a netCDF file.

result.msg:
Finding large-scale mesoscale convective systems (MCSs) in SciSpark

This notebook will demonstrate using SciSpark to:

  • read in netCDF files
  • mask areas in an array meeting a criteria
  • connect these areas via overlap between two time steps to form a graph object.
  • Search this graph object to find subgraphs meeting a minimum length criteria
  • Visualization
    These are all the steps conducted to identify and track mesoscale convective systems (MCSs) as outlined in Whitehall et al. 2014.

           Figure 1: The major steps of the the Grab 'em, Tag 'em, Graph 'em algorithm

For this demonstration, hourly brightness temperature NCEP/CPC MERG dataset over location 5S - 40N, 60E - 90W is used. More information about the NCEP/CPC 4km MERG Dataset used for this demonstration can be found here.

Useful references

  • Goyens, C., Lauwaet, D., Schröder, M., Demuzere, M. and Van Lipzig, N.P., 2012. Tracking mesoscale convective systems in the Sahel: relation between cloud parameters and precipitation. International Journal of Climatology, 32(12), pp.1921-1934.

  • Palamuttam, R., R. Marroquín Mogrovejo, C. Mattmann, B. Wilson, K. Whitehall, R. Verma, L. McGibbney, and P. Ramirez, 2015. SciSpark: Applying In-memory Distributed Computing to Weather Event Detection and Tracking. In 2015 IEEE International Conference on Big Data (Big Data) on, pp. 1959 - 1965.

  • Whitehall, K., C. Mattmann, G. Jenkins, M. Rwebangira, B. Demoz, D. Waliser, J. Kim, C. Goodale, A. Hart, P. Ramirez, M. Joyce, M. Boustani, P. Zimdars, P. Loikith, and H. Lee, 2014. Exploring a graph theory based algorithm for automated identification and characterization of large mesoscale convective systems in satellite datasets. Earth Science Informatics. DOI: 10.1007/s12145-014-0181-3

Note that in the nomenclature used in this notebook, a frame indicates the date and time associated with a netCDF file.

paragraphs.text:
%sh
rm /tmp/*.nc
rm -r /tmp/pngs/*

paragraphs.title: Import libs
Initialize The SciSpark Context
paragraphs.text: val ssc = new SciSparkContext(sc)

paragraphs.title: Load the data and set up environment
paragraphs.text:
val partCount = 4
val varNames =  List("ch4", "longitude", "latitude")
val variableName = "ch4"
val hdfspath = "hdfs://my-cluster:8020/data/MERGdata/" 
val hdfsOutputDir = "hdfs://my-cluster:8020/user/zeppelin/output"
val outputLoc = "output"
val WWLLNpath = "hdfs://my-cluster/data/WWLLN/"

val maxAreaOverlapThreshold = 0.65
val minAreaOverlapThreshold = 0.50
val outerTemp = 241.0
val innerTemp = 233.0
val convectiveFraction = 0.9
val minArea = 625
val nodeMinArea = 150
val minAreaThres = 16
val minGraphLength = 4

val outputDir = FileUtils.checkHDFSWrite(hdfsOutputDir)
val broadcastedWWLLNDF = ssc.readWWLLNData(WWLLNpath, partCount)

val sRDD = ssc.sciDatasets(hdfspath, varNames, partCount)

paragraphs.title: Add MetaData To The SciDataset
paragraphs.text:
val sampleDataset = sRDD.take(1)(0)
val lon = sampleDataset("longitude").data()
val lat = sampleDataset("latitude").data()

val labeled = MCSOps.recordFrameNumber(sRDD, variableName)

%md
## Find cloud elements and connect the cloud elements between frames
*Cloud elements* are defined as contiguous regions where the temperature is atleast 241.0K and an area is met. 241K is a reasonable brightness temperature threshold for deep convection in detection in the Tropics (Machado et al. 1998).

In order to observe features are forming over time, it is necessary to connect *cloud elements* between *frames*. The connection, referred to as an *edge*, is created between *cloud elements* of consecutive *frames* if: 
* the area between consecutive frames is >= 2400.00 squared_km
OR
* the area between consecutive frames is < 2400.00 squared_km and the convective fraction is < 0.9. The convective fraction is defined as the ratio of minimum to maximum brightness temperature

![Finding cloud elements](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/SciSpark/scispark_zeppelin_notebooks/master/images/sRDDtimeSeq.png)                          
               Figure 2: Illustration of how the cloud elements and edges are determined

This algorithm was originally developed for use in West Africa. As such, this criteria follows discussions in the literature about the microphysical characterization of MCS features in the area of interest and previous temperature threshold implementations (Bouniol et al. 2010, Machado et al. 1993, Mapes and Houze 1993, Goyens et al. 2011)

At the end of this step, a sparely connected graph representing the  cloud elements found and their connectivity through out the user defined datasets. 

Notice the **sciTensor** is being passed around and manipulated.

result.msg:
Find cloud elements and connect the cloud elements between frames

Cloud elements are defined as contiguous regions where the temperature is atleast 241.0K and an area is met. 241K is a reasonable brightness temperature threshold for deep convection in detection in the Tropics (Machado et al. 1998).

In order to observe features are forming over time, it is necessary to connect cloud elements between frames. The connection, referred to as an edge, is created between cloud elements of consecutive frames if:

  • the area between consecutive frames is >= 2400.00 squared_km
    OR
  • the area between consecutive frames is < 2400.00 squared_km and the convective fraction is < 0.9. The convective fraction is defined as the ratio of minimum to maximum brightness temperature

           Figure 2: Illustration of how the cloud elements and edges are determined

This algorithm was originally developed for use in West Africa. As such, this criteria follows discussions in the literature about the microphysical characterization of MCS features in the area of interest and previous temperature threshold implementations (Bouniol et al. 2010, Machado et al. 1993, Mapes and Houze 1993, Goyens et al. 2011)

At the end of this step, a sparely connected graph representing the cloud elements found and their connectivity through out the user defined datasets.

Notice the sciTensor is being passed around and manipulated.

paragraphs.title: Maintain The Time Series In The Parallel Environment
paragraphs.text:
val filtered = labeled.map(p => p(variableName) = p(variableName) <= 241.0)
val consecFrames = SRDDFunctions.fromRDD(filtered).pairConsecutiveFrames("FRAME")

paragraphs.title: Connect The Cloud Elements And Store Metadata On Each Node
paragraphs.text:
val edgeListRDD = MCSOps.findEdges(consecFrames, variableName, maxAreaOverlapThreshold, minAreaOverlapThreshold, convectiveFraction, minArea, nodeMinArea, minAreaThres)

edgeListRDD.cache()
edgeListRDD.localCheckpoint()

val MCSEdgeList = edgeListRDD.collect()
val MCSNodeMap = MCSOps.createNodeMapFromEdgeList(MCSEdgeList, lat, lon)
val broadcastedNodeMap = ssc.sparkContext.broadcast(MCSNodeMap)

paragraphs.title: Add Lightning data and write netCDFs
paragraphs.text:
MCSEdgeList.foreach(edge => {
    val (srcMCSNode, dstMCSNode) = MCSUtils.getMCSNodes(edge, MCSNodeMap)
    MCSOps.updateLightningWWLLN(srcMCSNode, broadcastedWWLLNDF)
    MCSOps.updateLightningWWLLN(dstMCSNode, broadcastedWWLLNDF)
    MCSUtils.writeEdgeNodesToNetCDF(edge, broadcastedNodeMap, lat, lon, false, "/tmp", null)
})

println("NUM VERTICES : " + MCSNodeMap.size + "\n")
println("NUM EDGES : " + MCSEdgeList.size + "\n")

val MCSNodeFilename: String = outputDir + System.getProperty("file.separator") + "MCSNodes.json"

val MCSEdgeFilename: String = outputDir + System.getProperty("file.separator") + "MCSEdges.txt"

result.msg:
NUM VERTICES : 75

NUM EDGES : 66


MCSNodeFilename: String = hdfs://my-cluster:8020/user/zeppelin/output/1486478368996/MCSNodes.json

MCSEdgeFilename: String = hdfs://my-cluster:8020/user/zeppelin/output/1486478368996/MCSEdges.txt

paragraphs.title: Find subgraphs
paragraphs.text:
val edgeListRDDIndexed = MCSOps.createPartitionIndex(edgeListRDD)
val count = edgeListRDDIndexed.count.toInt
val buckets = 4
val maxParitionSize = count / buckets
val subgraphs = edgeListRDDIndexed
  .map(MCSOps.mapEdgesToBuckets(_, maxParitionSize, buckets))
  .groupByKey()
val subgraphsFound = MCSOps.findSubgraphsIteratively(subgraphs, 1, maxParitionSize, minGraphLength, outputDir)

val subgraphsPath = outputDir + System.getProperty("file.separator") + "subgraphs-*"
val subgraphsRDD = MCCOps.loadSubgraphsFromFile(subgraphsPath, ssc.sparkContext)

paragraphs.title: Generate pngs
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
#create pngs
#TODO: do this in parallel in mapR job
import os, sys, glob

def make_imgs(currFile):
    import numpy as np
    import matplotlib
    matplotlib.use('Agg')
    
    import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
    plt.rcdefaults()
    
    from mpl_toolkits.basemap import Basemap, cm
    
    from netCDF4 import Dataset
    
    workdir = ''.join('/'+e for e in currFile.split('/')[1:-1])+'/'
    
    fh = Dataset(currFile, 'r')
    fhlats = fh.variables['lat'][:]
    fhlons = fh.variables['lon'][:]
    fhbt = fh.variables['CE_brightness_temperature'][:]
    fh.close()
    
    lon1, lat1 = np.meshgrid(fhlons, fhlats)
    
    plt.figure(figsize=(3,2))

    mp = Basemap(projection = 'merc', llcrnrlon = min(fhlons), urcrnrlon = max(fhlons), llcrnrlat = min(fhlats), urcrnrlat = max(fhlats), resolution = 'l')
    x1, y1 = mp(lon1, lat1)
    clevs1 = range(190,240,2)
    cs1 = mp.contourf(x1, y1, fhbt, clevs1, cmap=cmap)
    
    # Add Grid Lines
    mp.drawparallels(np.arange(-6., 45., 0.5), labels=[1,0,0,0], fontsize=8)
    meridians = mp.drawmeridians(np.arange(-95., 65., 0.5), labels=[0,0,0,1], fontsize=8)
    for m in meridians:
        try:
            meridians[m][1][0].set_rotation(45)
        except:
            pass
    
    mp.drawcoastlines(linewidth = 0.25)
    mp.drawcountries(linewidth = 0.25)
    
    ti = currFile.split('/')[-1].split('_')[0]
    plt.savefig(workdir+'pngs/'+ti+'.png')
    
    plt.close()
   
# get the list of the netCDFs generates
workdir = '/tmp/'

ceLists = glob.glob(workdir+'F*.nc')
if not os.path.exists(workdir+'pngs/'):
    os.makedirs(workdir+'pngs/')

#create the colorbar
import matplotlib
matplotlib.use('Agg')

from matplotlib import pyplot as plt
 
import numpy as np
from mpl_toolkits.basemap import cm
cmap = matplotlib.cm.jet_r

fig = plt.figure(figsize=(9, 1.5))
ax1 = fig.add_axes([0.05, 0.80, 0.9, 0.15])
norm = matplotlib.colors.Normalize(vmin=190, vmax=240)
cb = matplotlib.colorbar.ColorbarBase(ax1, cmap=cmap, norm=norm, orientation="horizontal")
cb.set_label('Brightness Temperature in deg_K')
plt.savefig(workdir+'pngs/colorbar.png')
plt.close()

for t in ceLists:
    make_imgs(t)

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
workdir = '/tmp/'
# get the data from the scala env
subGraphNodeMapPy2n = z.get("subGraphsMapPy")
subGraphNodeMapPy = subGraphNodeMapPy2n.split('\n')

graphVizPy2n = z.get("graphEdgesVis")
graphVizPy = graphVizPy2n[5:-1].split(',')

# get the node metadata
nodeMetaData = generate_node_data(workdir, subGraphNodeMapPy)
generate_svgs(1, graphVizPy, nodeMetaData, workdir)
draw_sub_graph(1, graphVizPy, nodeMetaData, workdir)
